mn120:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn120:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn120:2.1: “I shall teach you rebirth by choice.
mn120:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn120:3.1: “Take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
mn120:3.3: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’
mn120:3.4: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
mn120:3.5: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
mn120:3.6: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.

mn120:37.6: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
mn120:37.7: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
mn120:37.8: And, mendicants, that mendicant is not reborn anywhere.”
mn120:37.9: That is what the Buddha said.
mn120:37.10: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
